title: Understanding Root Mean Square Speed
text: The root mean square (rms) speed of a gas molecule is related to its kinetic energy. How does the mass of a molecule affect its speed if the temperature is constant?

title: Kinetic Energy and Molar Mass
text: Remember that kinetic energy is given by the formula $$KE=\frac{1}{2} m v^2$$, where $$m$$ is the mass and v is the velocity. How does the mass of a molecule affect its velocity if the kinetic energy is constant?

hintAnswer: The molecule with the smaller molar mass will have a higher speed.
title: Relating Molar Mass to Speed
text: If two gas molecules have the same kinetic energy, but different molar masses, which one will have a higher speed?
choices: The molecule with the smaller molar mass will have a higher speed.
The molecule with the larger molar mass will have a higher speed.
Both will have the same speed.

title: Temperature and Speed
text: Consider how temperature affects the speed of gas molecules. Does temperature have the same effect on all molecules regardless of their molar mass?

hintAnswer: The larger the molar mass of the gas molecule, the lower the root mean square (rms) speed of the gas molecule.
title: Final Conclusion
text: Based on your understanding of kinetic energy and temperature, which statement about the rms speed of gas molecules with different molar masses is correct?
choices: The larger the molar mass of the gas molecule, the lower the root mean square (rms) speed of the gas molecule.
The larger the molar mass of the gas molecule, the higher the root mean square (rms) speed of the gas molecule.
The root mean square (rms) speed is only dependent on temperature, so all of the gas molecules have the same rms speed.
